thread.title: Blue Jays’ dry spell continues on wet night in Kansas City
thread.title_full: Blue Jays’ dry spell continues on wet night in Kansas City | Toronto Star

title: Blue Jays’ dry spell continues on wet night in Kansas City
text:
KANSAS CITY—Somewhere in this now miserable road trip, the Blue Jays lost their offence.
It’s been almost three games now since that offence, the most potent in the majors, has actually scored a run.
The scoreless stretch now dates back to the fifth inning in Tuesday’s game in Chicago — a span of 24 innings — after a rain-delayed 3-0 loss to the Royals before 31,558 at Kauffman Stadium.
This Friday night tilt was almost washed out by rain, a downpour which extended 127 minutes past the scheduled starting time.
Facing lefty Danny Duffy at 2-4, and 5.41 entering the game, Toronto managed just four of their six hits overall, and progressed as far as third base only once in dropping to 2-6 on this 10-game road trip.
The offence’s disappearing act comes at a difficult time for the Jays, who have struggled on the road this season (now 18-27), and are desperate to establish something positive before the all-star break.
The dry spell is not expected to last, but it is compounding concerns with the pitching staff, who are surrounded by trade talk and expectations that management will make some kind of bolstering move prior to the July 31 trade deadline.
In the bigger picture, Toronto is now 7-13 with two games to go before the all-star break. Over the past two seasons, the team has stumbled into the break on similar losing streaks, including a 7-14 tailspin in 2014.
While the Jays remain a playoff viable team talentwise, the numbers scream out that the roster needs help to bring the playoff picture together.
“We’ve cooled off with the bats, no doubt about it, but we’ve seen some good pitching on this road trip, too,” Jays manager John Gibbons said. “That’s gonna happen in this game, and I’m surprised it’s taken this long.”
Starting pitching wasn’t a problem with the Jays Friday night. Marco Estrada put in a gutsy outing against the best team in the American League and worked two outs into the seventh inning, scattering two runs on nine hits and making some tremendous pitches and outs with runners in scoring position.
Estrada was at his best following a scary moment in the first inning when he was drilled on the right shin off a wicked come backer by Eric Hosmer.
Estrada looked doubtful to stay in the game, limping around the mound, but wanted no part of an early exit.
“I couldn’t feel my leg, to be honest with you,” Estrada said.
“But I didn’t want to come out. Gibby came up to me and said, either you can or you can’t, so I said I can.”
Estrada got the inning ending out on one pitch after being struck, a detail which helped him remain in the game.
“Yeah, that definitely helped … I was able to come in and get it wrapped quickly, and stay on it,” Estrada said. “It hurt going up and down stairs but not out on the mound, so I was happy to stay in the game and give the team a few more innings.”
His teammates, meanwhile, floundered against Duffy, then ran into the Royals lights-out bullpen trio of Kelvin Hererra, Wade Davis and closer Greg Holland. That’s the best 7-through-9 inning combo in baseball, and one of several reasons the Royals — barring catastrophic setbacks — are going to the post season again this season.
Toronto remains a post-season threat in the American League East, but are clearly no match for the Royals at the moment.
Friday’s loss marked the club’s seventh defeat in its last nine games; more importantly, the Jays have gone 10-15 since their 11-game winning streak came to a halt June 14.
The offence outscored opponents 114-105 over that 25-game stretch, but remains largely unable to win low-scoring games. With Friday’s two-run loss, the Jays have fallen to 13-29 in games decided by two runs or fewer.
Jays hitters, who have boarded 15 games with 10 or more runs this season, went 0-8 with runners in scoring position Friday.
Friday’s loss also dropped Toronto below .500 (44-45) for the first time since June 8.
